_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0    EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

This document has been prepared to document how US Foodservice complies with the requirements set forth under EPA's Chemical Accidental Prevention Provisions (40 CFR Part 68).  

This plan has been developed specifically to address the requirements applicable to the use of anhydrous ammonia at US Foodservice.  Each of the following sections provides a general overview of the requirements and defines the design attributes, documentation, and actions that are established to comply with those requirements.  In most instances, US Foodservice has already developed measures and systems that provide compliance with 40 CFR Part 68 rules as a result of other regulatory programs and requirements.  This document does not replicate that information but rather provides cross-references to the applicable existing documentation.  In those instances where information was developed specifically to comply with the Part 68 requirements, that information is contained in this document.

1.1.    Corporate Commitment to Safety

US Foodservice is committed in providing to all employees a work environment that is free from recognized health and safety hazards.  Accordingly, our goal is achieving and sustaining a"Zero Accident Tolerance" through communication, information, and training.  To this end, we are dedicated to the concept that all employees receive the proper orientation and are provided with the means necessary to ensure the environment remains as safe and healthful as possible.

1.1.1.    It is the policy of US Foodservice to:

1.1.1.1    Provide safe working conditions, proper tools, and personal protective equipment.

1.1.1.2    Comply with all federal, state, and local occupational health, safety, and environmental laws and regulations.

1.1.1.3    Provide and sustain a high level of commitment to ensure all employees have a safe and healthy work environment in which to work.

1.1.1.4    Ensure, through training, and when necessary disciplinary action, that all employees

work in a safe manner.

1.1.1.5    Educate and/or train all employees in safe work practices, and ensure that each employee fully understands his or her job, equipment, techniques, and methods to reduce the risk to himself or herself and their co-workers.

1.1.2.    Encourage all employees to "Think Safety", so that safety habits developed and practiced at work carry through to non-work related activities.

1.1.3.    US Foodservice's aim is to provide a professional service as efficiently as possible while minimizing the use of toxic materials whereever and whenever prudent.  In this effort our highest priority will be the proactive pursuit of cost-effective process changes that reduce or eliminate the use and/or generation of hazardous toxics at the endpoint of service.  Where hazardous toxics cannot be eliminated, improving controls to handle these substances will be explored and implemented wherever possible.

1.1.4.    US Foodservice has prepared a facility safety policy and procedures program specifically tailored for the facility. In addition, a Process Safety Management Program has also been established and implemented regarding the ammonia refrigeration system process.  It is the responsibility of the designated facility personnel to carry out these programs.

1.1.5.    The first duty of US Foodservice employees is to exercise care in the performance of his/her work tasks to prevent an accident to him/herself, co-workers, the general public or equipment.  Safety-consciousness must take precedence over expedience, and is required as a condition of continued employment of all employees at all levels of the organization.

1.2.    US Foodservice Facility Description

US Foodservice is a cold storage / distribution facility that receives and prepares the re-shipment of frozen and refrigerated food products to their end users.  Products are received and shipped via truck 24 hours a day, six days a week.

1.2.1.    The substance regulated under the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisio

ns (40 CFR 68) that is located on site, in various locations and quantities is anhydrous ammonia.

1.2.2.    Anhydrous  Ammonia is utilized on site for the "Process System". The ammonia is contained and used in various vessels, compressors, piping, and evaporators used throughout the refrigeration process.  

1.3.    Worst Case Release Scenario

1.3.1.    As stipulated in EPA guidelines, 40 CFR Part 68.25(b)(1) the worst-case release scenario was calculated and the results are on file at the US Foodservice facility. 

1.4.    Alternate Case Release Scenario

1.4.1.    The alternative release scenario was also calculated according to the EPA guidelines and is on file at the facility. 

1.5.    Emergency Response Program

1.5.1.    US Foodservice is equipped with an emergency information system.  Evacuation plans are placed throughout the facility to inform personnel in an emergency relating to the accidental release of ammonia, or other emergencies that may be encountered.  There are specific procedures that all employees must follow in the event of release; which can be found in the US Foodservice Emergency Action Plan.  These procedures include evacuation of personnel, notification of authorities and actions to be taken to stop, or mitigate the emergency if it is safe to do so.

1.5.2.    Plant personnel have received required emergency training as outlined in OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.38.

1.5.3.    The Boca Raton Fire Department has visited the facility to review the process operations, safety systems and discussed emergency response coordination.
